prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as Scott.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Helen, Scott, Jonathan, Eric, Jacob, Michelle, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Scott's) goal: Deceive others, avoid detection, and eliminate villagers.

{secret}

prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as Helen.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Helen, Scott, Jonathan, Eric, Jacob, Michelle, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Helen's) goal: Act openly and collaboratively to identify werewolves.

{secret}

Here is the context of the interaction:


Conversation Starts:

Turn #0: [Game] State: Night_werewolf. The game begins!

Turn #1: [Game] Entering state: Night_seer

Turn #2: [Game] Entering state: Night_witch

Turn #3: [Game] Jonathan was killed by werewolves!
[Game] Entering state: Day_discussion

Turn #4: Helen: said: "Jonathan was killed by the werewolves tonight. I'm not sure who the werewolves are yet, but I think we should focus on discussing the possible suspects based on who might have been targeted. Since Jonathan was killed, it's possible he was a werewolf or someone who was not a threat to the group. I'll be watching for any suspicious patterns in the rest of the night and during the day discussions."

Turn #5: Scott: said: "Jonathan's death is suspicious—maybe he was a werewolf trying to get eliminated, or maybe the wolves are targeting key players. I don't trust Eric's sudden kill; he acted right after me, which feels coordinated. Let’s keep an eye on him and Michelle—they’re both quiet so far."

Turn #6: Eric: said: "Scott, you're jumping to conclusions. I killed Jonathan because he seemed too eager to point fingers—now that he's gone, we can focus on real threats. Helen, you're right to be cautious, but don't ignore Michelle. She hasn't said anything since the start. That’s more suspicious than me acting on instinct."

Turn #7: Jacob: said: "Eric's claim about killing Jonathan because he was 'too eager' seems inconsistent with the rules—only werewolves can kill during the night, and we don't know who exactly killed him. Also, he just used the save potion on himself, which is suspicious. I trust Helen's caution and believe we should keep a close eye on Michelle, who hasn't spoken much. Let's not jump to conclusions yet, and focus on the pattern of who's been active and who's been silent."

Turn #8: Michelle: said: "I appreciate the discussion everyone has had. I want to clarify that I have not been silent—I’ve been listening carefully to the conversation and trying to stay neutral. I don’t have any private knowledge about who killed Jonathan, and I’m not making accusations. I agree with Jacob that we should avoid jumping to conclusions. Let’s keep the focus on patterns: who has spoken, who has stayed quiet, and how the night events unfold. I’m open to any suggestions and will continue to support a fair and collaborative discussion."
